titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

did.repository: University of Delaware Special Collections Department Morris Library, 181 South College Avenue Newark, DE 19717-5267

bioghist.p: James A. Moore (d. 1999) was professor emeritus of chemistry and biochemistry at the University of Delaware. During World War II, Moore served as an army private at White Sands, New Mexico, with a group of expatriate German rocketeers, led by Werner von Braun. After the war, Moore earned his doctoral degree at Pennsylvania State University and worked for six years as a chemist for Parke Davis in Detroit before joining the Universityâ€™s Department of Chemistry in 1955. Moore earned international recognition for his work as an organic chemist specializing in novel heterocyclic systems, and was editor of the Journal of Organic Chemistry for 25 years. He was a Gordon Conference section chairman for many years and coauthor of a popular textbook in organic chemistry. He was admired as a teacher and as a mentor and adviser to Ph.D. candidates and postdoctoral associates. He retired from the University in 1988.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of notebooks, printed volumes, notes and other records of James A. Moore. There are eight notebooks, the topics of which include heterocyclic studies, 1958-1961; bromoketones, 1947-1948; cheiranthus cheiri seeds, 1952-1958; the chemistry of steroidal sapogenins, 1950; excerpts from research literature on psychotropic mushrooms and LSD, 1950s; and notes kept by Rita Hetzell on chemistry experiments, 1983. There are two published volumes in the collection: John R. Dyer's Applications of Absorption Spectroscopy of Organic Compounds, 1965; and Ralph Shriner and Reynold Fuson's The Systematic Identification of Organic Compounds, 1940. The collection also includes correspondence with Frederick Uhle, 1950-1964; correspondence related to the pennogenin problem, 1956-1963; annual evaluations and peer reviews from the University of Delaware, 1976-1986; a syllabus and notes for a 1989 course on biological evolution; lantern slides for presentations; and measuring tools.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

otherfindaid.p: An inventory is available in the repository.
